appeal.appeal_text: The frozen flag is not required in .NET designs because C# has two types of unchangeable fields ("const" and "readonly") that must be identified differently on the diagram. The field in question is unambiguously identified as "frozen" to developers and other users of the diagram because it is marked with the <<const>> stereotype. If you agree that developers looking at the diagram would have no doubts as to whether the field is changeable or not, please consider changing the rating for this item to 4.
appeal.appeal_response: Ok, I can raise the score, but IMHO the <<const>> and <<readonly>> are used to describe syntax. From the semantic view the frozen modifier should still better be used. The item is changed to recommended.

appeal.appeal_text: The "match" is a delegate method used in a base component after performing all the relevant argument checking. Specifically, the DynamicRole of Authorization 2.0 null-checks the context argument, making it impossible to pass null into the delegate. If you agree that null-checking is not required when non-nullness is guaranteed by the base component, please consider changing the rating for this item to 4.

(1) Although the groupName will not be set to an empty string, the knowledge of it is important to the reader of method documentation. The readers of the variable documentation must know whether the field is null or not to decide if they must check it each time they access it; the knowledge that the field is also non-empty is secondary, because it is not used anywhere beyond the constructor. (2) As far as the initial value of <<const>> fields goes, it must be specified somewhere, but not necessarily in the corresponding field of the object properties (this is similar to describing exceptions in @throws tags of the arguments section vs. explaining them in free-form test - both ways are acceptable, as long as the information is complete). I prefer specifying the <<const>> value in the free-form documentation to make the class easier to fit on the page, and to hide non-essential items from the face of the diagram (after all, only developers care about the values of private and internal const fields). If you agree that all constant values are provided by the variable documentation, please consider changing the rating for this item to 4.

In addition to the requirements stated in the requirements specification, this component also supports recursive searches and supplies to durable user keys to its users. Certain LDAP servers can perform recursive searches natively, but Active Directory requires considerable programming effort to do that. It is an important user feature, too - when it is present in the product, vendors let users know about it. For example, WebSphere Application Server Express offers recursive searches for group membership, so IBM has a documentation page explaining it (http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wasinfo/v6r0/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.websphere.express.doc/info/exp/ae/tsec_directindirectldap.html). The durable keys part required an even larger effort to design - without this additional requirement I would have been able to fit the entire design into a single class, cutting the scope in half (I would combine the group matcher and the AD connector, while the key, the context, the manager and the exception would be gone). If you agree that the features are useful and that the functionality that they cover was not in the requirements, please consider changing the rating for this item to 4.

I completely agree that the configuration use case is at the correct level - it's neither too low nor too high. The reason I did not include it is that the use case is not accessible through the APIs of the component. In the past, I included configuration use cases only when my designs provided a non-programming way to deal with something that was expected to require programming (for example, when I used the expression evaluator in places where a programming approach based on delegates or interfaces was expected). If you agree that showing non-API use cases is optional when they are not replacing an API-based use case, please consider changing the rating for this item to 4.
appeal.appeal_response: I think that even admin can be considered as a user/actor interacting with the component (high level) and such a use-case alerts the user right away that configuration is part of this component's life cycle.

appeal.appeal_text: >>> I do not see a reason to have #ActiveDirectoryUserKey(info:SerializationInfo, context:StreamingContext) being protected. <<< I am reasonably certain that it is a .NET convention to mark serialization constructors as protected or private. Keeping it protected wouldn't hurt even though the class is internal (in .NET "internal" and "protected" can be combined to designate items that behave as protected for classes inside the package, but are invisible outside the package), in case it is subclassed in the same package. If you agree with this reasoning, please consider changing the rating for this item to 4.

This is what the "using" construct is for in all of my code examples working with DirectoryEntry. According to the book I mentioned in the component specification, this way of disposing the DirectoryEntry is preferred over the explicit calls to the close/dispose methods.

Like I said in my other appeal, the preferred way of disposing of DirectoryEntry objects is through the "using" construct that implicitly calls the dispose method (as opposed to explicit calls to close/dispose). If you agree that since the developers do not call these methods explicitly it is OK to hide them from the diagram, please consider changing the rating for this item to 4.
appeal.appeal_response: Yes, this was granted in that appeal so it is granted here as well.

subjective_response.response_text: No sub-packages needed.
ActiveDirectoryConnector#ConfigurationNamespaceName should be marked frozen.
New useful functionalities provided.
Algorithms are defined properly.
Used properly.
The design could easily accommodate reasonable enhancements to the component.
I'm ok with the usage.
The API is consistent, powerful, flexible, and is easy to understand.
The designer mentions thread safety and provides correct arguments to back it up.
Well scoped.
The design did not need any sub-package.
ActiveDirectoryConnector#ConfigurationNamespaceName should be marked frozen.
The types are appropriate and the collection interfaces are used where appropriate.
Trivial issues. UserNotFoundException#LoginName and login should better use exactly the same name(except the cases) due to the naming convention.
Language features are used correctly.
Documentation is complete and provides full details to the developer.
Demonstrates each of the requirements correctly in a clear fashion using a customer scenario.
Not found.
Some lifelines in SDs are overlaped.
The values column for configuration table in the CS should describe the valid (and/or invalid) values, rather than give an example. e.g. use "Any non-null, non-empty strings" instead of "scott".
The constructors should always be put before other methods defined, ActiveDirectoryGroupMatcher doesn't do so.
Set should be abstract class, but in the CD you show it in the way of normal class.
Solid design with some enhancements beyond the requirement. Only a few minor issues left.
Very good treatment of the requirements. There are some useful extras provided.
Excellent coverage.

I do not see how the 1.2.4 requirement: "Active Directory Configuration" is shown in the use-case. While it might be considered low level I think that it important to depict this since it is a direct requirement and involves the application as the user/actor.
All 脗聭complicated脗聮 interactions have been described.

Only concrete classes are provided and there is no really pluggability provided (for example ActiveDirectoryUserKey could be first designed as an interface) but in general this design is not hard to extend.
Yes, and goes beyond with usage of Set 1.0 component as well.
Fairly easy to use.
Good discussion of the topic.
None created but I see no need for any.
I do not see a reason to have #ActiveDirectoryUserKey(info:SerializationInfo, context:StreamingContext) being protected. ActiveDirectoryUserKey is already package itself. --- Appealed ---
ActiveDirectoryConnector.-ConfigurationNamespaceName : string shoudl be marked 'frozen' No Points taken since const implies frozen
The provided exception is warranted.
Looks complete.
DirectoryEntry is not being properly disposed from what I can see. (i.e. there is not active way of closing/disposing of it) --- Appealed ---
Fairly informative.
I think that the details are good enough. One aspect that I would improve is the DirectoryEntry lifecycle treatment. Should this be disposed at some point? --- Appealed ---
Looks very nice.
Some spelling: (1) 'daya' ---> 'data'
grammar/Meaning: (1) 'contains the loging name' I think that 'log-in' is what was meant here.
A very well presented solution.
Looks like an excellent submission. Some minor fixes are needed.
The requirements are met
match is invalid name. It should be Match
The UseCase diagram title should be more descriptive.
Pretty good design.
